CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research:
Low-Resolution Sampling with Generalized Thresholds

Jian Li, Lee Swindlehurst, and Mojtaba Soltanalian 

Abstract

Quantization of signals of interest is a necessary first step in digital signal processing applications. When signals across a wide frequency band are of interest, a fundamental tradeoff between sampling rate, amplitude quantization precision, cost, and power consumption is encountered. The investigators study low resolution sampling techniques with general thresholds, which are affordable, technically feasible, easy to apply, energy-efficient, and consistent with technological trends. The enormous gains in capacity and spectral efficiency, for example, that could be provided by a successful millimeter wave (mm-wave) massive multiple-input multiple output implementation could have a revolutionary effect on the performance of wireless systems nearly everywhere we use them: at home, at work, at school, commuting via public transportation or by plane, shopping, at restaurants, recreational venues, sporting events, and so on. Besides consumer applications, there are many military- and security-related scenarios where our systems could be used.

This project involves advancing fundamental knowledge in developing dynamic energy-efficient and cost-effective sampling techniques and applies engineering principles to address the critical needs of several important and related applications. Specifically, this project involves  addressing significant open questions, including deterministic identifiability, performance bounds, and impact of thresholding pattern on spectrum sensing and array processing, radio frequency interference mitigation, and mm-wave communications to gain fundamental insights into the novel paradigm of low resolution sampling with general thresholds, devising novel signal processing algorithms, including effective and efficient sparse signal recovery techniques and parametric maximum likelihood methods for enhanced performance, and evaluating and demonstrating the performance using measured data. This project also involves preparing students for engineering in the 21st century through the incorporation of practical design and problem-solving techniques into both the education curriculum.

Intellectual Merit

In order to support the exponentially increasing demand for fast and reliable mobile wireless connectivity, a number of different technologies have been studied in recent years. One of these is the use of arrays of many antennas in wireless receivers that allow the systems to exploit the variations in how wireless signals propagate in different spatial directions. Such large arrays can dramatically increase the amount of data that can be supported by a wireless system, both in terms of the amount of data per user and the number of users accessing the network at the same time. These benefits are symbiotic with the fact that many wireless networks are moving to higher and higher frequency bands, which allows large arrays of antennas to be constructed with relatively small dimensions. However, the biggest roadblock to deploying such arrays is that they are expensive and they consume a significant amount of power. The research sponsored by this award has focused on how to make such large-array systems more energy efficient ? how to decrease the cost, complexity and energy consumption of the hardware without causing significant impairments to their performance gains. In particular, we have been studying the impact of hardware simplifications that reduce the number of bits of digital samples that are used to represent the analog wireless signals. Our research has shown that the use of lower-resolution analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) and digital-to-analog converters (DACs) can provide an exponential savings in energy consumption with manageable losses in signal fidelity.

One of the most important outcomes of our work is to demonstrate the superiority of low-resolution sampling compared to competing hybrid digital-analog approaches, in which some processing of the signals occurs in the analog domain instead of confining all processing to the digital domain. To compare the relative performance of these two approaches, we have calculated the performance along two dimensions, energy consumption and communication rate, and found that all-digital systems that operate with about 3-4 bits of resolution provide a superior trade-off between these two dimensions. This has a significant impact for future system development, and we are hearing from our colleagues in industry that the all-digital approach is gaining favor over the hybrid digital-analog approach that was initially proposed by researchers. It is our firm belief that the majority of large-array wireless systems that will be deployed in the future will be all-digital, not only because of the energy-rate trade-off, but also because all-digital systems provide increased flexibility and simpler designs.

The other major outcomes of our project have focused on methods for reducing the inevitable performance loss of low-resolution systems. Two promising methods have been extensively studied. In the first, we propose the use of a very special type of data conversion referred to as spatial sigma-delta (SSD) sampling. SSD sampling can exploit situations in which the signals arriving at the large array are known to be confined to a certain region of angles (e.g., as is the case for an array on a tower or in a large auditorium) or when the antennas in the array can be placed more closely together. In these situations, the ADCs and DACs can exploit correlations between the signals at each antenna to reduce the error that comes from quantizing the signals with very few bits. This approach can reduce the loss due to the low-resolution sampling down to as little as one dB. The second method we have investigated is the use of deep neural networks that learn the very complicated statistics of low-resolution data (which are very difficult to analyze mathematically except in simple cases) and are able to near-optimally decode the received digital data. The performance of these receivers is significantly better than prior approaches based on simplified assumptions about the data and the architecture of the receivers.

Broader Impacts

Three Ph.D. students have been trained using support from this project, two of which have graduated and are now working in the U.S. high-tech industry (at Qualcomm and Apple). They were able to gain invaluable experience in wireless communications systems, hardware implementation trade-offs, and new deep learning techniques that will benefit them throughout their careers. One of the students who graduated is female. The research themes studied in the project have been transferred to the classroom, where both undergraduate and graduate students are exposed to recent advances in machine learning and modeling the statistical behavior of highly non-linear systems (such as low-resolution data converters). Finally, senior project student groups advised by the PI have design devices that use the low-resolution data converters for some simple sensing applications, and learned about the trade-offs associated with energy consumption and system performance.
